segment.source: Create and register a background task
segment.target: Create and register a background task

segment.source: Create a background task class and register it to run when your app is not in the foreground.
segment.target: Create a background task class and register it to run when your app is not in the foreground.

segment.source: Create and register a background task
segment.target: Create and register a background task

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: IBackgroundTask
segment.target: IBackgroundTask

segment.source: BackgroundTaskBuilder
segment.target: BackgroundTaskBuilder

segment.source: BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler
segment.target: BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler

segment.source: Create a background task class and register it to run when your app is not in the foreground.
segment.target: Create a background task class and register it to run when your app is not in the foreground.

segment.source: Create the Background Task class
segment.target: Create the Background Task class

segment.source: You can run code in the background by writing classes that implement the IBackgroundTask interface.
segment.target: You can run code in the background by writing classes that implement the IBackgroundTask interface.

segment.source: This code will run when a specific event is triggered by using, for example, SystemTrigger or MaintenanceTrigger.
segment.target: This code will run when a specific event is triggered by using, for example, SystemTrigger or MaintenanceTrigger.

segment.source: The following steps show you how to write a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.
segment.target: The following steps show you how to write a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.

segment.source: Before getting started, create a new project in your solution for background tasks.
segment.target: Before getting started, create a new project in your solution for background tasks.

segment.source: Add a new empty class for your background task and import the Windows.ApplicationModel.Background namespace.
segment.target: Add a new empty class for your background task and import the Windows.ApplicationModel.Background namespace.

segment.source: Create a new project for background tasks and add it to your solution.
segment.target: Create a new project for background tasks and add it to your solution.

segment.source: To do this, right-click on your solution node in the Solution Explorer and select Add-New Project.
segment.target: To do this, right-click on your solution node in the Solution Explorer and select Add-New Project.

segment.source: Then select the Windows Runtime Component (Universal Windows) project type, name the project, and click OK.
segment.target: Then select the Windows Runtime Component (Universal Windows) project type, name the project, and click OK.

segment.source: Reference the background tasks project from your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project.
segment.target: Reference the background tasks project from your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project.

segment.source: For a C++ app, right-click on your app project and select Properties.
segment.target: For a C++ app, right-click on your app project and select Properties.

segment.source: Then go to Common Properties and click Add New Reference, check the box next to your background tasks project, and click OK on both dialogs.
segment.target: Then go to Common Properties and click Add New Reference, check the box next to your background tasks project, and click OK on both dialogs.

segment.source: For a C# app, in your app project, right click on References and select Add New Reference.
segment.target: For a C# app, in your app project, right click on References and select Add New Reference.

segment.source: Under Solution, select Projects and then select the name of your background task project and click Ok.
segment.target: Under Solution, select Projects and then select the name of your background task project and click Ok.

segment.source: Create a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.
segment.target: Create a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.

segment.source: The Run method is a required entry point that will be called when the specified event is triggered; this method is required in every background task.
segment.target: The Run method is a required entry point that will be called when the specified event is triggered; this method is required in every background task.

segment.source: Note The background task class itself - and all other classes in the background task project - need to be public classes that are sealed.
segment.target: Note The background task class itself - and all other classes in the background task project - need to be public classes that are sealed.

segment.source: The following sample code shows a very basic starting point for a background task class:
segment.target: The following sample code shows a very basic starting point for a background task class:

segment.source: If you run any asynchronous code in your background task, then your background task needs to use a deferral.
segment.target: If you run any asynchronous code in your background task, then your background task needs to use a deferral.

segment.source: If you don't use a deferral, then the background task process can terminate unexpectedly if the Run method completes before your asynchronous method call has completed.
segment.target: If you don't use a deferral, then the background task process can terminate unexpectedly if the Run method completes before your asynchronous method call has completed.

segment.source: Request the deferral in the Run method before calling the asynchronous method.
segment.target: Request the deferral in the Run method before calling the asynchronous method.

segment.source: Save the deferral to a global variable so it can be accessed from the asynchronous method.
segment.target: Save the deferral to a global variable so it can be accessed from the asynchronous method.

segment.source: Declare the deferral complete after the asynchronous code completes.
segment.target: Declare the deferral complete after the asynchronous code completes.

segment.source: The following sample code gets the deferral, saves it, and releases it when the asynchronous code is complete:
segment.target: The following sample code gets the deferral, saves it, and releases it when the asynchronous code is complete:

segment.source: The following steps are completed in one of your app classes (for example, MainPage.xaml.cs).
segment.target: The following steps are completed in one of your app classes (for example, MainPage.xaml.cs).

segment.source: Note You can also create a function dedicated to registering background tasks - see Register a background task.
segment.target: Note You can also create a function dedicated to registering background tasks - see Register a background task.

segment.source: In that case, instead of using the next 3 steps, you can simply construct the trigger and provide it to the registration function along with the task name, task entry point, and (optionally) a condition.
segment.target: In that case, instead of using the next 3 steps, you can simply construct the trigger and provide it to the registration function along with the task name, task entry point, and (optionally) a condition.

segment.source: Register the background task to run
segment.target: Register the background task to run

segment.source: Find out if the background task is already registered by iterating through the BackgroundTaskRegistration.AllTasks property.
segment.target: Find out if the background task is already registered by iterating through the BackgroundTaskRegistration.AllTasks property.

segment.source: This step is important; if your app doesn't check for existing background task registrations, it could easily register the task multiple times, causing issues with performance and maxing out the task's available CPU time before work can complete.
segment.target: This step is important; if your app doesn't check for existing background task registrations, it could easily register the task multiple times, causing issues with performance and maxing out the task's available CPU time before work can complete.

segment.source: The following example iterates on the AllTasks property and sets a flag variable to true if the task is already registered:
segment.target: The following example iterates on the AllTasks property and sets a flag variable to true if the task is already registered:

segment.source: If the background task is not already registered, use BackgroundTaskBuilder to create an instance of your background task.
segment.target: If the background task is not already registered, use BackgroundTaskBuilder to create an instance of your background task.

segment.source: The task entry point should be the name of your background task class prefixed by the namespace.
segment.target: The task entry point should be the name of your background task class prefixed by the namespace.

segment.source: The background task trigger controls when the background task will run.
segment.target: The background task trigger controls when the background task will run.

segment.source: For a list of possible triggers, see SystemTrigger.
segment.target: For a list of possible triggers, see SystemTrigger.

segment.source: For example, this code creates a new background task and sets it to run when the TimeZoneChanged trigger is fired:
segment.target: For example, this code creates a new background task and sets it to run when the TimeZoneChanged trigger is fired:

segment.source: You can add a condition to control when your task will run after the trigger event occurs (optional).
segment.target: You can add a condition to control when your task will run after the trigger event occurs (optional).

segment.source: For example, if you don't want the task to run until the user is present, use the condition UserPresent.
segment.target: For example, if you don't want the task to run until the user is present, use the condition UserPresent.

segment.source: For a list of possible conditions, see SystemConditionType.
segment.target: For a list of possible conditions, see SystemConditionType.

segment.source: The following sample code assigns a condition requiring the user to be present:
segment.target: The following sample code assigns a condition requiring the user to be present:

segment.source: Register the background task by calling the Register method on the BackgroundTaskBuilder object.
segment.target: Register the background task by calling the Register method on the BackgroundTaskBuilder object.

segment.source: Store the BackgroundTaskRegistration result so it can be used in the next step.
segment.target: Store the BackgroundTaskRegistration result so it can be used in the next step.

segment.source: The following code registers the background task and stores the result:
segment.target: The following code registers the background task and stores the result:

segment.source: Handle background task completion using event handlers
segment.target: Handle background task completion using event handlers

segment.source: You should register a method with the BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler, so that your app can get results from the background task.
segment.target: You should register a method with the BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler, so that your app can get results from the background task.

segment.source: When the app is launched or resumed, the mark method will be called if the background task has completed since the last time the app was in the foreground.
segment.target: When the app is launched or resumed, the mark method will be called if the background task has completed since the last time the app was in the foreground.

segment.source: (The OnCompleted method will be called immediately if the background task completes while your app is currently in the foreground.)
segment.target: (The OnCompleted method will be called immediately if the background task completes while your app is currently in the foreground.)

segment.source: Write an OnCompleted method to handle the completion of background tasks.
segment.target: Write an OnCompleted method to handle the completion of background tasks.

segment.source: For example, the background task result might cause a UI update.
segment.target: For example, the background task result might cause a UI update.

segment.source: The method footprint shown here is required for the OnCompleted event handler method, even though this example does not use the args parameter.
segment.target: The method footprint shown here is required for the OnCompleted event handler method, even though this example does not use the args parameter.

segment.source: The following sample code recognizes background task completion and calls an example UI update method that takes a message string.
segment.target: The following sample code recognizes background task completion and calls an example UI update method that takes a message string.

segment.source: Go back to where you registered the background task.
segment.target: Go back to where you registered the background task.

segment.source: After that line of code, add a new BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler object.
segment.target: After that line of code, add a new BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler object.

segment.source: Provide your OnCompleted method as the parameter for the BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler constructor.
segment.target: Provide your OnCompleted method as the parameter for the BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler constructor.

segment.source: The following sample code adds a BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler to the BackgroundTaskRegistration:
segment.target: The following sample code adds a BackgroundTaskCompletedEventHandler to the BackgroundTaskRegistration:

segment.source: Declare that your app uses background tasks in the app manifest
segment.target: Declare that your app uses background tasks in the app manifest

segment.source: Before your app can run background tasks, you must declare each background task in the app manifest.
segment.target: Before your app can run background tasks, you must declare each background task in the app manifest.

segment.source: If your app attempts to register a background task with a trigger that isn't listed in the manifest, the registration will fail.
segment.target: If your app attempts to register a background task with a trigger that isn't listed in the manifest, the registration will fail.

segment.source: Open the package manifest designer by opening the file named Package.appxmanifest.
segment.target: Open the package manifest designer by opening the file named Package.appxmanifest.

segment.source: Open the Declarations tab.
segment.target: Open the Declarations tab.

segment.source: From the Available Declarations drop-down, select Background Tasks and click Add.
segment.target: From the Available Declarations drop-down, select Background Tasks and click Add.

segment.source: Select the System event checkbox.
segment.target: Select the System event checkbox.

segment.source: In the Entry point: textbox, enter the namespace and name of your background class which is for this example is RuntimeComponent1.ExampleBackgroundTask.
segment.target: In the Entry point: textbox, enter the namespace and name of your background class which is for this example is RuntimeComponent1.ExampleBackgroundTask.

segment.source: Close the manfiest designer.
segment.target: Close the manfiest designer.

segment.source: The following Extensions element is added to your Package.appxmanifest file to register the background task:
segment.target: The following Extensions element is added to your Package.appxmanifest file to register the background task:

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: You should now understand the basics of how to write a background task class, how to register the background task from within your app, and how to make your app recognize when the background task is complete.
segment.target: You should now understand the basics of how to write a background task class, how to register the background task from within your app, and how to make your app recognize when the background task is complete.

segment.source: You should also understand how to update the application manifest so that your app can successfully register the background task.
segment.target: You should also understand how to update the application manifest so that your app can successfully register the background task.

segment.source: Note Download the background task sample to see similar code examples in the context of a complete and robust UWP app that uses background tasks.
segment.target: Note Download the background task sample to see similar code examples in the context of a complete and robust UWP app that uses background tasks.

segment.source: See the following related topics for API reference, background task conceptual guidance, and more detailed instructions for writing apps that use background tasks.
segment.target: See the following related topics for API reference, background task conceptual guidance, and more detailed instructions for writing apps that use background tasks.

segment.source: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
